Award.AwardTitle: Organization of Terpene Specialized Metabolism in Plant Roots

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
As multicellular organisms, plants rely on a highly organized system of metabolic pathways. Compared to the animal immune system, plants have developed a complex and diverse 'specialized', or secondary, metabolism as an important defense mechanism against attack by other organisms. Since insects and microbial pathogens use different strategies of feeding or invasion, plant chemical defenses need to be tissue and cell-type specific but, at the same time, maintain a sufficient level of plasticity. This project investigates how plants coordinate and fine-tune specialized metabolic pathways in different cell types and subcellular compartments. Focus is placed on the metabolism of volatile terpenes in roots of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. Terpenes are the most common specialized metabolites with significant functions in plant defense. The study explores the genetic organization and biochemical function of terpene biosynthesis modules consisting of enzymes coordinated by root cell-type specific and stress-induced expression. Furthermore, the project addresses the question of how strictly the formation of terpene metabolites is limited to particular root cell types and examines aspects of the organelle-specific regulation of terpene metabolism in roots.

Broader Impacts:
Expected results may allow developing novel strategies for sustainable control of agricultural soil-borne pests and pathogens by engineering root chemical defenses in crop plants. The project integrates high school and undergraduate student education into an active research project by introducing novel experimental concepts for the pre-college education program "Partnership for Research and Education in Plants (PREP)" and its undergraduate-level extension (PREPu), developed at Virginia Tech. For PREPu, experiments will be implemented as a laboratory module in the undergraduate/graduate course "Introduction to Chemical Ecology". Plant mutants generated in this research project will be tested in both educational programs for their defense properties against root-attacking organisms. The study integrates K-12 and undergraduate student learning through investigation and promotes understanding of interdisciplinary and translational life science. The project further provides interdisciplinary training and transformative education for one postdoctoral fellow, one graduate student, and two undergraduate students. Research on this project strongly supports graduate education in the Molecular Plant Sciences Program at Virginia Tech and recruitment of individuals from groups underrepresented in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Plants use highly coordinated metabolic defense systems to combat attack by other organisms. This project has investigated the genetic organization, cell type specificity, and spatial-functional relationships of terpene metabolism in the chemical defense of roots of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. Terpenes are the most common compounds with specialized functions in plant defense.

We have found ecotype-specific variation in the root terpene specialized metabolome, especially of 20-carbon diterpenes. Different Arabidopsis ecotypes produce mixtures of diterpene compounds that are either unique to this species or have been rarely reported in higher land plants. We have shown that one group of these compounds named rhizathalenes contributes to the defense of Arabidopsis roots by a “central diffusion” mechanism (Vaughan et al., 2013). As semi-volatile metabolites, rhizathalenes are biosynthesized in plastids of the cells of the root stele, from where they protect the surrounding cell layers against herbivory by diffusion through these tissues.

Another major finding of this project is that the same type of functional molecules can be produced by alternative pathways in a single plant in a tissue specific manner. In particular, we found that the biosynthesis of common volatile homoterpenes in Arabidopsis roots is a consequence of gene cluster evolution and is distinctly different from its biosynthetic route in aboveground tissues (Sohrabi et al., 2015). A mutant-based approach showed that the root-specific pathway and formation of homoterpenes contributes to the defense of Arabidopsis roots against infection by Pythium irregulare, a common root rot pathogen of plants. The finding exemplifies the evolution of biosynthetic plasticity in different plant tissues and suggests that this plasticity arises from interaction with different organisms above- and belowground.

As of today, the outcomes of this project have been described in 10 publications with additional publications pending. The study has impact on future research to assess the role of plant metabolic diversity in plant-organismal interactions. Furthermore, the project has opened new directions of interdisciplinary research for investigating the multifunctionality of volatile compounds in the plant rhizosphere, especially their effects on root-associated microbial communities (Junker and Tholl, 2013).


Broader Impacts:

The findings of this project may allow developing novel strategies for sustainable control of agricultural soil-borne pests and pathogens by engineering root chemical defenses in crop plants.

The project has provided interdisciplinary training for two postdoctoral fellows, three graduate students, one master’s student, and nine undergraduate students, six of which were supported by REU supplemental grants. Several of these contributors have continued careers in academia or scientific research (Qiang Wang – professor at Sichuan Agricultural University, China; Sungbeom Lee – senior researcher, Advanced Radiation Technology Institute, Korea; Martha Vaughan - senior research scientist at USDA-ARS-NCAUR, Peoria; Reza Sohrabi – postdoctoral fellow, University of Michigan; Sean Smith – laboratory assistant in enology laboratory, Charlottesville, Virginia; Peter Nixon – research assistant, University of Minnesota; Ayla Wilk – graduate assistant, Virginia Tech).
